I beg to differ over better bridges. The industrial truss style of the Bay Bridge's eastern span has been replaced with a modern suspension bridge. Although it may be something to look at, it lacks the gritty steel so befitting of Oakland's shipping ports with towering cranes and rusted containers. The new span was shoddily built and with poorly made parts. The Golden Gate still represents an era of fine workmanship. As for the Bay Bridge, there are doubts it will withstand The Big One.

My favorite bridge is the 92, connecting Hayward in the East to Half Moon Bay on the coast. It is a minimalist structure and you'll feel as though you are driving on the bay itself.

One story that impressed me a lot is that the name of a person simply doesn't matter since it is meant only to identify a person and it has nothing to do with what a person does in his or her profession. The story is as below.

During the good olden days, every parent whether rich or poor used to keep their kids under the care of gurus for proper learning and upbringing till their education gets completed. The gurus used to name the disciples even. One such disciple was named " Lowly ". He was a very wise and helpful student but was very unhappy with his name. He requested his guru to change the name. The guru asked him to visit a few villages and then return.

One day while walking in a village he happened to see some people carrying a dead person. He asked a person about the name of the dead person. Promptly he got the reply as " Life ". He asked the other person as to how a person named " Life " can die. That person replied that everyone has to die one day whether a person is named " Life "or " Death ".

In another village he saw a lady beating a girl. He asked the lady for beating the girl. The lady told that the girl was her slave and that she asked her to earn some money but she didn't. " Lowly " paid her some money and requested her not beat her and told her that the girl would surely earn some other day. He asked a passerby as to What was the name of the girl. To his utter shock, he learnt the name of the girl to be " Rich ".

I love this column even though I don't read much. For the past two weeks or so I have been reading books at a stretch for few hours a day. I have finished reading two bound books comprising fifteen small books of roughly 30 pages each, printed on both sides and twenty other small books. These books are meant for children in pictorial form like comic books but can be enjoyed by everyone. These are mostly moral and witty story books and also include stories about the achievers and Patriots mostly Indian.

Twenty small books that I read also include the stories of Marie and Pierre Curie and Kalpana Chawla. I mention one story here.

Ramakrishna Tenali was a humourous and clever poet. One night he happened to see thieves in his huge yard hidden somewhere. So he thought of a plan to get rid of them. He told his wife loudly to put the ornaments in a box and store them in their well so that the ornaments can be safe but in low voice in fact he asked his wife to dump the box with stones. His wife obliged him accordingly. The thieves threw out the water from the well tirelessly and ended up fruitlessly. Ramakrishna loudly thanked the thieves for helping them by providing water to their large garden.

We purchased these story books from Readers Digest for sending them to my daughter in Ann Arbor MI so that she can read and explain the stories to our granddaughter, who is sixteen months old now and who in turn can read them later provided the books remain intact.

The ACA is a change in the legal regime for the individual insurance market. The key elements are: (1) guaranteed issue of insurance without regard to health status; (2) community rating of the individual pool, with consumers paying rates only based on their age and their smoking status; (3) a mandate (enforced by modest tax penalties) that individuals all carry coverage (to prevent free-riders). Medicaid was expanded to cover the poorest citizens.

The beneficiaries of Obamacare extend well beyond those on Medicaid. People with pre-existing conditions can now get covered (here in North Carolina, you could be denied coverage for being modestly overweight). People who paid high premiums because of chronic diseases got reduced prices (because of community rating). People with incomes low enough to qualify for subsidies got help paying for insurance (in North Carolina, the median income for a family of four will qualify you for a subsidy).

You are ignoring the carbon dioxide cost to transport wood waste from the Southeastern US to Europe.

You are also ignoring some basic economics about the production of wood waste. Consumption of wood for paper production in the US has declined because the paper and pulp is being produced in South America. Wood waste is produced as a byproduct of manufacturing wood products. To the extent that that business is declining (which consumes its own waste to power its own manufacturing), there is very little wood waste available for export.

Since the Europeans are obligated to burn biofuels, trees in the Southeastern US are being harvested with pellets as their only use. And it is not just plantation pine, it is also hardwood that is in place to filter rainwater before it works its way to our waterways.

Ebmem --- I have included the additional CO2 for processing and transportation. Only about 20% more is still only around a thousant of the global warming potential of burning coal.

If some tree farms are being used solely for pellets it remains a thousand times better than burning coal.

Fekete (Brussels, Belgium) --- Thank you for your reply to my comment. I hope to convince you that I am right and the EU rules are approximately correct.

First of all, despite the fact that I live further from the southeastern portion of the USA than you do from Moscow, I do know something about the state of the forestry industry there. Those are all tree farms, the term plantation being anathema since 1865 CE. The tree farmers are in some distress between the decline in paper production, construction wood production and even the hardwood products industries.

I agree entirely that only one entity can lay claim to the CO2 benifits of burning biomass. I know of no double dipping.

A large portion of what is cut currently is simply waste. Often enough the portion of the waste which is hauled to the mill is simply burnt to be rid of it. Whatever portion is waste, more than half, if it can be beneficially used by turning into pellets, produces some additional income for the tree farmers.

Since the global warming potential for biomass is only about one thousant for the equivalent amount of burning coal, the EU rule applied to the pellets alone is very close to complete accounting, so close as to be within measurement error.

I hope I have written enough to convince you. If not, ask further.

A major reason behind the rising premiums is that many healthier consumers stayed in "transitional" plans that were extended due to the uproar over cancelled plans in late 2013.  These customers are disproportionately healthy, which led them to be offered especially low rates prior to 2014.  When these "grandmothered" plans eventually expire, these healthier customers will enter the regular ACA marketplace and improve the risk pool of these plans.

Delightful essay. It ain't easy being human these days. We get a bad rap because of all the wars, corruption, crime, brutality, needless ignorance, etc.

Let's all take a deep breath. It feels good to be human. You are right that we identify most strongly through our bodies. Think of hands and feet; the absence of a tail, which we only share with the great apes.

Our modern ideological systems have done a good job convincing us that we are independent individuals but don't we really prefer, on the most part, to identify with groups: our family, sports team, school, company, drinking buddies, chess club, church, town, and country?

Dogs, cats, horses, etc., these mammals are also the easiest to domesticate, and the one we identify the closest with - the dog is very much like humans in identifying with groups or packs.

Most of the groups that we belong to can somehow manage to live alongside other groups while minimizing conflict and just getting along. It's the exceptions that get the spotlight, but the vast majority of our time spent in groups is beneficial. That's where we really shine compared to other animals. Can one even count the number of groups one belongs to? That's the number of different ways that we cooperate with each other.
